Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a representation of Lagrangian mechanics in which the velocity components are measured relative to a frame that is not related to any local coordinates on the configuration space. This approach offers more flexibility than the original formalism of Lagrange, while keeping a clear distinction between system configurations and velocities. Known to be an effective and powerful tool in finite-dimensional continuous-time mechanics, this formalism introduced by Georg Hamel has not yet been fully developed for systems with infinitely-many degrees of freedom. The project is aimed at systematic study of the formalism in the infinite-dimensional setting, understanding its variational structure, its applications to dynamics of infinite-dimensional systems with nonholonomic constraints, including stability of a liquid-filled rigid body subject to nonholonomic constraints, and Lyapunov function construction.

Systems with infinite number of degrees of freedom arise in many applications in engineering and industry. Examples include flexible structures and rigid bodies interacting with fluids. This project develops the mathematics required to model and simulate the behavior of such complex mechanical systems. This work on the mechanics of systems will further integrate mathematics and theoretical engineering. The results of the project will be useful in theoretical analysis, simulations, control, and study of the long time behavior of multi-body dynamics and complex mechanical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hamel's formalism should be viewed as a natural development of the Euler-Lagrange formalism that simplifies the structure of the equations of motion of mechanical systems and enables one to perform analysis of mechanical systems more effectively. The key idea is to use differnt frames for measuring system's position and velocity. This approach originated in the work of Euler, Lagrange, and Poincare; Hamel made this approach systematic for finite-dimensinal systems.

The outcomes pf the project include:

  1. The development of Hamel'd formalism for infinite-dimensional and field-theoretic systems. This includes systems with velocity constraints. In particular, formalism for studying dynamics of systems with infinite number of constraints in the presence of symmetry has been obtained. The developed formalism has been shown to be useful in analysis, such as establishing existence and uniqueness of solutions of a particular field-theoretic mechanical system with velocity constraints.
  2. Construction of variational Integrators for field theories with one spatial independent variable based on Hamel?s formalism has been carried out. Such integrators were confirmed to perform well and to be capable of simulations of constrained field-theoretic mechanical systems to which other numerical techniques could not be effectively applied. The use of separate frames of the continuous formalism naturally extended to the use of separate discretization meshes (such as staggered meshes) for the fields describing system's state.
  3. The study of interconnections between the matching stabilization technique and the inverse problem of calculus of variations. This lays out a framework for the development of more general controlled Lagrangians for feedback stabilization of equilibria and relative equilibria of underactuated mechanical systems. The strengths of the matching techniques include (i) natural applicability to problems of mechanical origin and (ii) effectiveness in obtaining stability conditions through the Lyapunov function approach.

On the broaded impact side, the outcomes could be useful in practical problems of the dynamics of multibody systems with infinite-dimensional components (such as fluids and deformable bodies), in problems of fluid-structure interaction, in problems where mechanics is coupled with electromagnetism, etc. as the results offer an approach that is (i) more flexible and more universal than the standard Eulerian and Lagrangian descriptions of continuum mechanics; (ii) by design, makes it easy and straightforward to incorporate constraints tha often are used to model interconnections; and (iii) may lead to construction numerical algorithms that utilise system's natural behavior and structure.
